Diplomacy Authority
Will Address Club
Dr. Dexter Perkins, widely
known as an outstanding authority
on the Monroe Doctrine, and who
is at present conducting the Shaw
lectures on that subject, has consented to address the International
Relations Club at a luncheon to be
held on Wednesday, March 16, at
12:30 P. M.
Although the subject of his address is not definitely known, any
one who has heard Dr. Perkins will
realise that, regardless of topic, the
listener is assured of a keen and
delightfully interesting discussion.
The luncheon, which will be held
in parlor "B" of Levering Hall,
will be 35c, and everyone is welcome to attend.

Accepting as a challenge a recent rumor that they had been

last week that they were glad to
answer to every conceivable point

The rumor, which was given publicity in the News-Letter, was to
the effect that the Liberal Club has
been adopting a most partisan
standpoint with regards to the persons whom they have been inviting
to address them at their weekly
meetings. An unofficial statement
attributed to the R. 0. T. C. dedared that these speakers have been
entirely p:icifistic in sentiment, and
tint the militaristic attitude has
been wholly neglected. The NewsLetter was also scored by this report. it being said that no publicity
was ever given to militaristic
opinions.
Ask Military Men To Speak
In response to these charges, the
Liberals claim that Major McKinney, of the Hopkins R. 0. T. C.,
has himself addressed the Club
-upon a 1)!'evious occasion. They
said, moreover, that since they are
anxious to be as unbiased as possible in their attitude toward current questions, that they extend a
cordial invitation to members of
the Military Department to speak
at their meetings as soon as it may
be possible. However, according to
Capt. Silkman, it has been the policy

Economist Ignores Depression;
Fines Students For Lateness
Overworked Bailiff Collects Fines From Late-comers In Dr,
Mitchell's Classes-Money Is Used To Aid
Unemployed
Dr. Broadus Mitchell-our well
known economist, ecclesiastical
investigator, and (to the frosh)
professor who prefers to be "on
the level" when speaking to assemblies-has put into effect a
system by which the latecomer to
class is distressed, as it were, into
being less of a problem.
Is Fined
Our la ecomer, upon entering
after the final bell, is openly declared late, and fined ten cents by
the bailiff. Said fine, then having
been collected by the treasurer, is
duly entered recorded by the
auditor in his ledger. Only after
this is the delinquent eligible to
participate in class proceedings.
Bailiff Worked To Death
Needless to say, when in use,
the whole machine is kept welloiled by professorial remarks. It
may be noted also that the bailiff
is, by far, the most important of-ficer. He is as responsible for the
material welfare and comfort of
the class as Dr. Mitchell is for its
enlightenment and amusement.
His duty is to see that the radiators are on; that the heat therefrom escapes through the windows, which he opens; to run errands; to see that the bells get

fixed; and that the clocks run
correctly. His position is furthermore unique in that he is the
ultimate authority in all disputes
and may enforce his decisions
with blows; in that he serves as
the butt of all sarcastic remarks;
and in that he passes, no matter
what happens ("if he doesn't,"
Dr. Mitchell has remarked, it's
his own fault.")
The plan was originated by Dr.
Wheeler of the department of En~­
lish, and probably because of its
economic nature, its interesting
and amusing mechanism, its efficacy, and its quality, has appealed
to Dr. Mitchell. In order to make
clear this last phase, the economist
declared that the system makes for
a deeper appreciation of the unemployed masses.
Charity Benefits
The 1 :30 section has ordained
that its funds shall go to charity;
hence, late comers in this group
are made to realize that through
their laziness the unemployed are
kept from starving. However, the
8 :30 class, being totally devoid of
altruistic motives, proposes to
finally indulge in a spree of some
sort (ice cream cones, perhaps).

Paul Sabin's orchestra is hailed
by New York a ncliences in particular as" being one of the corning
bands of the year. }t has had a
36-week run on Broadway with
the show "Good News," and has
been featured at the Park Central
Hotel, the Palais d'Or, and the
Delmonico and Manhattan Tower
Hotels. It has filled engagements
with the Coll1mbia and National
Broadcasting Companies, and is
especially popular with Princeton
men. Commercial radio contracts
and college prom engagements
throughout the East, are slated for
the group ·within the next few
rnonths. Members of the Ball
Committee have been enthusiastic
in their recommendation of the
players.
Yoted as one of the most enjoyable social eyents of last year, the
ball is expected to far surpass all
previous achievements. It is one
of the few projects which the I1~ter­
fraternity Board plans each season,
and has always received strong
support.
Dancing will be from 10 to 3.

F reshman at Chicago U.
Just Couldn't Answer
One of the freshmen at the
University of Chicago did what
vve've been tempted to do more
than once, when in despair of
answering an examination, he
wrote on the paper, "Only God
knows the answers ;o these
questions." You can imagine the
shock when the paper was returned with the following note:
"God gets an A; you get an F."

Diplomacy Authority
Will Address Club
Dr. Dexter Perkins, widely
known as an outstanding authority
on the Monroe Doctrine, and who
is at present conducting the Shaw
lectures on that subject, has consented to address the International
Relations Club at a luncheon to be
held on Wednesday, March 16, at
12:30 P. M.
Although the subject of his address is not definitely known, any
one who has heard Dr. Perkins will
realise that, regardless of topic, the
listener is assured of a keen and
delightfully interesting discussion.
The luncheon, which will be held
in parlor "B" of Levering Hall,
will be 35c, and everyone is welcome to attend.

Economist Ignores Depression;
Fines Students For Lateness
Overworked Bailiff Collects Fines From Late-comers In Dr,
Mitchell's Classes-Money Is Used To Aid
Unemployed
Dr. Broadus Mitchell-our well
known economist, ecclesiastical
investigator, and (to the frosh)
professor who prefers to be "on
the level" when speaking to assemblies-has put into effect a
system by which the latecomer to
class is distressed, as it were, into
being less of a problem.
Is Fined
Our la ecomer, upon entering
after the final bell, is openly declared late, and fined ten cents by
the bailiff. Said fine, then having
been collected by the treasurer, is
duly entered recorded by the
auditor in his ledger. Only after
this is the delinquent eligible to
participate in class proceedings.
Bailiff Worked To Death
Needless to say, when in use,
the whole machine is kept welloiled by professorial remarks. It
may be noted also that the bailiff
is, by far, the most important of-ficer. He is as responsible for the
material welfare and comfort of
the class as Dr. Mitchell is for its
enlightenment and amusement.
His duty is to see that the radiators are on; that the heat therefrom escapes through the windows, which he opens; to run errands; to see that the bells get

News - Letter Discontinues Friday Issue
of Campus Paper

'\DAMS DECLAMATION CONTEST
SCHEDULED FOR THURSDAY'S ASSEMBLY.

fixed; and that the clocks run
correctly. His position is furthermore unique in that he is the
ultimate authority in all disputes
and may enforce his decisions
with blows; in that he serves as
the butt of all sarcastic remarks;
and in that he passes, no matter
what happens ("if he doesn't,"
Dr. Mitchell has remarked, it's
his own fault.")
The plan was originated by Dr.
Wheeler of the department of En~­
lish, and probably because of its
economic nature, its interesting
and amusing mechanism, its efficacy, and its quality, has appealed
to Dr. Mitchell. In order to make
clear this last phase, the economist
declared that the system makes for
a deeper appreciation of the unemployed masses.
Charity Benefits
The 1 :30 section has ordained
that its funds shall go to charity;
hence, late comers in this group
are made to realize that through
their laziness the unemployed are
kept from starving. However, the
8 :30 class, being totally devoid of
altruistic motives, proposes to
finally indulge in a spree of some
sort (ice cream cones, perhaps).
